did.abstract: Member of the Michigan State Senate, House of Representatives, Ann Arbor City Council, and Mayor of Ann Arbor; records include handwritten notes on policy issues, collected research materials, and news clippings related to Brater’s service as a member of the Michigan State Senate and House of Representatives.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The collection was received from Elizabeth S. Brater (donor no. 10478) in 2011.

accruals.p: Periodic additions to the records are expected.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is closed to research until January 1, 2031.

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Regents of the University of Michigan, except for Brater’s handwritten notes, to which she retains copyright.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Elizabeth S. Brater papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Elizabeth Brater is a former member of the Michigan State Senate (2003-2010) and House of Representatives (1995-2000), Mayor of Ann Arbor (1991-1993) and member of the Ann Arbor City Council (1988-1993). She is a member of the Democratic Party. Prior to entering politics, Brater was a writer and editor and taught writing at the University of Michigan.

Brater is particularly well-known as a leader in the areas of the environment and mental health. As both a state Senator and Representative, Brater sponsored numerous bills focused on protecting the environment. She was named Sierra Club Environmentalist of the Year in 1996, Clean Water Action Great Lakes Lawmaker of the Year in 2005, Jane Elder Environmentalist of the Year in 2006, and received the Michigan League of Conservation Voters Environmental Leadership Award in 2004.

As a mental health advocate, Brater worked to ensure that people with mental illnesses were in treatment rather than in jail or homeless shelters. She received several awards for her work in this area as well, including the Michigan Alliance for the Mentally Ill Legislator of the Year Award and the Association of Children's Mental Health Legislator of the Year Award in 1998 and the Michigan Psychiatric Society Mental Health Advocate Award in 2000. During her years in the legislature, Elizabeth Brater focused a great deal of attention on the issue of the prevention of criminalization of people with mental illness (PWMI). Many people refer to this public policy issues as "jail diversion," but Brater felt this label was inaccurate. Jail diversion refers to diverting PWMI from the jail after they have already been arrested, while her policy objective was to prevent PWMI from being arrested in the first place though a series of preventative steps, such as educating law enforcement personnel about how to interact with PWMI and giving PWMI access to the mental health system. A second prevention stage, if arrest did occur, was the establishment of a mental health court to allow PWMI charged with a crime to be diverted to mental health treatment, rather than pursue the adjudication. She adopted the term Treatment Alternatives to describe this public policy objective.

In addition to her service at the state level, Brater was active in Ann Arbor city governance. She was elected as the first woman mayor in 1991, and represented Ann Arbor's Third Ward on the City Council from 1988 to 1991. As Mayor she secured passage of the city's weekly recycling collection program and led the effort to launch the city's materials recovery facility. She also worked to increase cooperation between Ann Arbor and its neighbors and improve the efficiency of city government.

Elizabeth Brater was born in Boston, Massachusetts in 1951 and graduated from the University of Pennsylvania with a B. A. in English (1973) and an M. A. in History (1976). She has been involved in many community and environmental organizations including the Sierra Club, the Ecology Center, and the League of Women Voters. She is married to Enoch Brater, and moved to Ann Arbor in 1975 when he accepted a position as an English professor at the University of Michigan. The Braters have two children who graduated from the Ann Arbor Public Schools.

scopecontent.p: The Brater collection consists of eight series: Environment and Natural Resources, Mental Health, Judiciary, Other Policy Files, Legislative Files, Subject Files, News Clippings, and Other Office Files. The collection's strength lies in its documentation of Brater's activities in the areas of environmental issues and mental illness treatment programs as a member of the Michigan Senate and House of Representatives.

The first series Environment and Natural Resources, documents Brater's work on behalf of environmental issues, including conservation, toxic waste, solid waste, and water use. The material includes Brater's notes, collected research materials, and copies of bills and amendments proposed in both the House and Senate. The series contains material organized according to topic, House and Senate legislative files, and a subseries of subject files organized alphabetically. The files cover Brater's service in both the House and Senate.

Land Division Act and Other Land Use Legislation 1999-2001

Natural Resources and Environmental Protection Act
Natural Resources and Environmental Protection Act
SB 252, Natural Resources and Environmental Protection Act 2003
SB 250-253, National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System (NPDES) 2003

scopecontent.p: The second series, Mental Health, documents Brater's efforts on behalf of improved state mental health services. Materials in the series include notes and research materials on topics related to mental health in prisons, community mental health, children, treatment alternatives, and a FOIA request related to jail diversion programs. Material is arranged alphabetically by subject.

did.unittitle: University of Michigan School of Social Work Commencement Speech 2007
Alliance for the Mentally Ill (AMI) Lawsuit 1999
Children, Better Access to Mental Health Services 2000-2003
Not Guilty by Reason of Insanity (NGRI) undated
Health Care Financing Administration (HCFA) Video Conference 2000

National Alliance for the Mentally Ill (NAMI), Washtenaw County 2005
Jail Diversion Materials from Gains Center 1996-1997
Department of Corrections and Department of Health 2006
"Criminalizing the Mentally Ill: The Abuse of Jails as Mental Hospitals," 1992

scopecontent.p: Judiciary, the third series, contains files related to Brater's service on the State Senate's Judiciary Committee. The files document Brater's positions on issues ranging from prisons to sexual assault laws.

did.unittitle: SB1388 Out of State Placement for Juvenile Delinquents 2004

scopecontent.p: The fourth series, Legislative Files, documents Brater's House and Senate legislative activity in areas other than mental health and the environment. Files include bill memos and requests, introduced bills, and research files related to specific bills.

did.unittitle: Council of State Governments, Midwestern Legislative Conference, Traverse City 2007
Press Release for Senate Democrats Environmental Agenda 2005
SB4, Compulsory School Attendance to Age 18 2003
Banning Household Batteries and Fluorescent Light Bulbs from Landfills and Municipal Solid Waste Incinerators 2003

scopecontent.p: The fifth series, Other Policy Files, documents Brater's involvement in several other state level policy issues. The issues are Agriculture, Land Use Council, Transportation, Education, Health Care, and Budget and Finance. Files include handwritten notes and research materials on these topics. The series is particularly strong in documenting Brater's positions on taxation issues.

did.unittitle: Notes on Michigan State University Extension's Better deigns for Development in Michigan course 2001
Notes on Michigan Legislative and Business Leaders forum on Growth Management 1999
SB4, Compulsory School Attendance to Age 18 2003
Single Business Tax, Detroit Chamber Plan undated

scopecontent.p: Subject files, the sixth series contains miscellaneous files on various policy topics from Brater's time in both the House and Senate. The series is split into Senate and House and the files are organized alphabetically by topic.

did.unittitle: Ypsilanti Community Utility Authority Incinerator Project 2003
Michigan Democrat Party Platform, Environmental Subcommittee 1996

scopecontent.p: The sixth series, News Clippings, documents news coverage of Brater's House and Senate career in local and state level newspapers.

Other Office Files, the seventh and final series, contains miscellaneous files related to local issues and Brater's career. The series contains a small selection of newsletters she sent to constituents as well as a photograph of the members of the Michigan State Senate during its 125th Anniversary year.

did.unittitle: Michigan State Senate, 125th Anniversary Assembly Photograph 2004
